member.name: T:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Actions.IEditAction
member.summary: Executes a complex action on a .

remarks.para: s are usually complex actions, which manipulate the (document, caret position, current selection, etc.). Examples are: Cut, Copy, Paste, Select All, Page-Down, etc.

An actions action is usually automatically triggered by the when it detects a certain keyboard shortcut. But you can also call actions manually from your application. For example: You can invoke an when the user selects 'Cut' from your application menu.
Action do not require additional parameters. They depend only on the current state of the (document, caret position, current selection, etc.).
To define a new key for the , you must write a class which implements this interface.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Document.DefaultDocument.GetFirstLogicalLine(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the first logical line for a given physical (visible) line.
member.returns: The logical line number.

remarks.para: A logical line is a line in the document, whereas a physical line is line that is rendered in the text editor. A physical line can contain multiple logical lines, for example when they are collapsed (see "folding").
The logical line numbers correspond with the line numbers drawn in the line-number margin. (Except that logical lines are 0-based and line-numbers drawn are 1-based.)
Example: lineNumber == 100, foldings are in the between 0..1 (2 folded, invisible lines). This method returns 102 as the 'logical' line number.
A visible line can contain several logical lines when it contains a (folded) folding. This method returns the first logical line that belongs to the visible line.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Document.DefaultDocument.GetLastLogicalLine(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the last logical line for a given physical (visible) line.
member.returns: The logical line number.

The logical line numbers correspond with the line numbers drawn in the line-number margin. (Except that logical lines are 0-based and line-numbers drawn are 1-based.)

The logical line numbers correspond with the line numbers drawn in the line-number margin. (Except that logical lines are 0-based and line-numbers drawn are 1-based.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Document.IDocument.GetFirstLogicalLine(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the first logical line for a given physical (visible) line.
member.returns: The logical line number.

remarks.para: A logical line is a line in the document, whereas a physical line is line that is rendered in the text editor. A physical line can contain multiple logical lines, for example when they are collapsed (see "folding").
The logical line numbers correspond with the line numbers drawn in the line-number margin. (Except that logical lines are 0-based and line-numbers drawn are 1-based.)
Example: lineNumber == 100, foldings are in the between 0..1 (2 folded, invisible lines). This method returns 102 as the 'logical' line number.
A visible line can contain several logical lines when it contains a (folded) folding. This method returns the first logical line that belongs to the visible line.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Document.LineSegmentTree
member.summary: Data structure for efficient management of the line segments (most operations are O(lg n)).

remarks.para: This implements an augmented red-black tree where each node has fields for the number of nodes in its subtree (like an order statistics tree) for access by index(=line number). Additionally, each node knows the total length of all segments in its subtree. This means we can find nodes by offset in O(lg n) time. Since the offset itself is not stored in the line segment but computed from the lengths stored in the tree, we adjusting the offsets when text is inserted in one line means we just have to increment the TotalLength of the affected line and its parent nodes - an O(lg n) operation. However this means getting the line number or offset from a LineSegment is not a constant time operation, but takes O(lg n).
Note: The tree is never empty, causes it to contain an empty segment.

The escape character followed by another escape character means the escape character was escaped like in @"a "" b" literals in C#. The default value '\0' means no escape character is allowed.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Utilities.WeakCollection`1
member.summary: A collection that allows its elements to be garbage-collected (unless there are other references to the elements).

remarks.para: Elements will disappear from the collection when they are garbage-collected.
The is not thread-safe, not even for read-only access! No methods may be called on the while it is enumerated, not even a or creating a second enumerator.
The does not preserve any order among its contents; the ordering may be different each time the collection is enumerated.
Since items may disappear at any time when they are garbage collected, this class cannot provide a useful implementation for and thus cannot implement the interface.

member.remarks: Runtime: O(n).

member.summary: Removes all elements from the collection.
member.remarks: Runtime: O(n).

member.summary: Checks if the collection contains an item.
member.returns: if the collection contains the specified item; otherwise, .
member.remarks: Runtime: O(n).

member.summary: Removes an element from the collection.
member.returns: if the item is found and removed, when the item is not found.
member.remarks: Runtime: O(n).

member.summary: Enumerates the collection.

member.summary: Finds the end of the identifier at the given offset.

remarks.para: An identifier is a single word consisting of letters, digits, or underscores. An identifier must start with a letter or underscore.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.TextHelper.LeadingWhitespaceToTabs(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts leading whitespaces to tabs.
member.returns: The converted line.
member.remarks:
This function takes a string and converts the whitespace in front of it to tabs. If the length of the whitespace at the start of the string was not a whole number of tabs then there will still be some spaces just before the text starts. the output string will be of the form:
zero or more tabs
zero or more spaces (less than tabIndent)
the rest of the line

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.TextBuffer.GapTextBufferStrategy
member.summary: Implements a text buffer using the 'gap text' strategy.

remark.para: Internal implementation: The text buffer is implemented as an array of characters. A gap is inserted at the position where characters are inserted or removed. This minimizes the number of copy operations and memory reallocations. Subsequent insert operations are just inserted into the gap - no memory copy/allocation. Only when the insert position changes or the gap is full the buffer needs to be restructured.

remarks.example: Here is an example how to use the pre-selection: Imagine you have method MyClass.MethodXyz(). When the user types myClass.Meth and then calls the completion window, you should use the string Meth as pre-selection. The completion window can automatically select the first entry that starts with Meth.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Completion.ICompletionDataProvider.PreSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets the pre-selection.

remarks.para: The pre-selection is string that is used to select the entry in the completion window, when creating the window. When no pre-selection is set, then no entry in the completion window will be selected.
remarks.example: Here is an example how to use the pre-selection: Imagine you have method MyClass.MethodXyz(). When the user types myClass.Meth and then calls the completion window, you should use the string Meth as pre-selection. The completion window can automatically select the first entry that starts with Meth.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Completion.Snippet.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that is inserted in the text editor if the snippet is selected.
member.remarks: As a special character snippets can contain the character '|'. This character marks the position where the caret will be placed after the snippet is expanded.
member.example:
Here is an example snippet that defines a while-loop. Note how the '|' is placed inside the parenthesis. When the user expands the snippet, the caret will be placed where the '|' is.
Snippet whileLoop = new Snippet("while", "while (|)\n{\n}", "while loop")

member.summary: If the caret is in insert mode typed characters will be inserted at the caret position

member.summary: Renders the caret.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.Caret._isValidationRequired
member.summary: Value indicating whether the current caret position needs to be validated.
member.remarks: The caret uses 'lazy validation': When a new caret position is set, the new position is not immediately updated. The position is validated as soon as someone accesses the position (via , , etc.). This is necessary for the following reasons: If someone sets, and independently the position might be invalid after the first component is set. Therefore the validation needs to be delayed until all components are set. Another reason is that during a longer update the document might invalid, so the caret cannot be validated immediately.

member.summary: Gets or sets the desired column (in pixels).
member.value: The 'prefered' xPos in which the caret moves, when it is moved up/down. Measured in pixels, not in characters!

member.summary: The text area control.
member.remarks: The controls the editing in the visible part of the document. This control renders all the elements that are tightly coupled with currently edited text: text view, line number margin, folding margin and icon bar margin. (Scrollbars and the horizontal ruler are not part of this control. They are part of the .)

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.TextView.FirstPhysicalLine
member.summary: Gets the first visible physical line.

remarks.para: A physical line is line that is rendered in the text editor, whereas a logical line is a line in the document. A physical line can contain multiple logical lines, for example when several files are folded (collapsed) into one.
The line numbers match the logical numbers: line number = (logical line + 1)

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.TextView.FirstLogicalLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the first visible logical line.
member.para: A logical line is a line in the document, whereas a physical line is line that is rendered in the text editor. A physical line can contain multiple logical lines, for example when several files are folded (collapsed) into one.
The line numbers match the logical numbers: line number = (logical line + 1)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Windows.TextEditor.BrushRegistry
member.summary: Contains brushes/pens for the text editor to speed up drawing. Re-Creation of brushes and pens seems too costly.
member.remarks: All brushes and pens are cached internally. When a new brush is requested the looks up the internal cache and returns the appropriate brush object. If the brush is not found in the cache, then a new brush is created and automatically cached.
